reviewText: I watched this movie, being a huge fan of the original. I found it compelling and entertaining. Sarah Butler is very easy on the eyes. The revenge scenes are very inventive and the effects are pretty cool. It's a watchable movie, but I have some problems with this movie.1. You are asking too much from me, wanting me to sympathize with a group of rapists. There are parts in the movie where the filmmakers don't realize what they're doing and the sympathy factor is shifting away from her and going to the guys. For example: Why do they have to have a scene where she smokes a joint, then tells the sheriff that the GUYS are the ones who left it there? Why in the beginning when Johnny is harmlessly flirting with her, she comes off as a snarky smart-ass? (How's that line working out for you?)? Why don't they explain what happened to the sheriff's daughter? I HATE the sheriff in this movie, but I find myself actually feeling bad for HIM, because we don't know the fate of the innocent little girl. WTF?2. The point of a rape-revenge movie is to make a PRO-female movie, not an ANTI-female movie. Jennifer disappears from the movie for a long time and we are stuck with the guys and it turns into like I KNOW WHAT YOU DID LAST SUMMER. We don't see the pain and horror Jennifer endured, like in the original. We see the guys and are spending time with them and they start coming off as decent guys who did one stupid thing, like how in I.K.W.Y.D.L.S., the kids are supposed to be good kids who did one stupid thing and are covering it up.3. Everyone complains about the LONG rape scene in the original, but trimming that section of the movie down, it comes off that the torture she inflicts on them is too much. One guy says he was raping her for 10 seconds, another said maybe 2 minutes, and she's out for most of it. Then look at the LONG, very gruesome torture she inflicts on the guys.4. Did she hide a credit card inside of her, or something? She comes back with a whole new wardrobe, a new car. Where did she get this stuff when the guys supposedly destroyed all her stuff? If they left something of hers behind, would it kill the filmmakers to add a scene of showing her finding it? Also, you have one guy videotaping the whole thing. She gets hold of the tape. Does she take the tape, get it to people she knows she can trust, get these guys and stick 'em in jail for a LONG time? Nope. She gives them back the tape and horribly kills these guys. Again, it's taking my sympathy away from her and turning it to the guys. Rape victims still don't have all the rights they should have, but they have FAR MORE than they did in 1978.To sum up: I am happy that the theme is still there: Rape is a terrible crime and if you rape a woman, you will pay consequences. It is there, but they complicated this movie too much and it shows just how much simpler the original is. Not a bad movie, but the original did a much better job making it's point than this one.
summary: Entertaining, but it's got quite a few problems.

reviewText: I remember seeing the posters for this one when my buddy and I were hanging out in Cali for the Weekend of Horrors horror con. I can't say I was thrilled at first when I hard the news although I had known it was just a matter of time before some schmuck saw reason to remake yet another cult film fave. I still was hellbent for election on seeing this film and even had hoped that I'd be able to catch it in the theaters. No such luck. I had to wait for DVD like everyone else but at least Walmart sells the standard DVD for $10 so who's complaining, right?If you've seen the original, you pretty much know what to expect here. If rape or brutality offends you, ISOYG isn't your movie. No other way to put it. This is not a Michael Bay film and I thank God for that. The film-makers here actually did their homework and delivered a very effective, if not powerful revenge flick which holds up well for repeated viewings and should satisfy most horror fans in the midst of things. Probability suggests I will grow to like this film even more with repeated viewings as there aren't any great horror films that I'm aware of anymore which are granted a major release.ISOYG is as brutal as they come but this is not an Eli Roth film as we have no sympathy for Jennifer Hill's victims. Well, maybe one. :-) Suffice to say, you are rooting for her all the way in the second half of the film as each lowlife is dispatched in the most gruesome fashion imaginable. Rest assured, she will have no mercy on any of them and will not back down until each one is punished severely.Definitely much more polished and professional than the seventies Grind house classic, the remake still manages to disturb it's viewer and doesn't let up. Whereas the original focused somewhat on the sexualized violence in our protagonist's revenge scheme, the modern day classic alleviates seduction altogether. Instead, Jennifer chooses to pit them against each other and takes her time to carry out the methodical revenge plan. Although we do not necessarily see how she escapes or her grand scheme of revenge, we are fully assured that justice will be served in the most bloody, cathartic sense of the word.What I found most disturbing about the revision is how her attackers torment the lead character as if we were watching Michael Haneke's Funny Games instead of your typical rape/revenge fare. I must confide that watching these men abuse Jennifer in every sense of the word before sexually assaulting her really took me out of my element and I couldn't but think of all the innocent women who have been raped through the years. Even a more hideous thought, they've been killed after being assaulted.Brave Sarah Butler. This is one role that really deserves the utmost praise and it's a shame we don't give Oscars for horror flicks very often. Camille Keaton is an awesome actress and I couldn't imagine anyone who could pull off this role but Sarah Butler is outstanding as Jennifer Hills. In fact, the supporting actors are very convincing as well which is a strong suit considering most of the cast in the original looked very wooden.Thumbs up sky high! It's hard to tell if the ISOYG is really just a fluke or if we can expect more great endeavors from the cast/crew but I'm definitely sold on this effort. As a long time horror fan and lover of films which address the male encroachment issue, this is one powerful piece of film-making. See it if you handle it!!

reviewText: I haven't seen the original movie yet (have it on order from Netflix) so can't compare the two yet.I can't say I enjoyed "I Spit On Your Grave" because I don't believe it is the type of movie most people ENJOY.  But it was haunting, thought provoking, viscerally wrenching.  I think, as a woman, it really had an impact on me.  What would I do in the same circumstances?  Maybe not as extreme as the victim in the movie but who really knows how far we will go unless we are pushed over the edge of all reason.The physical rape scenes were hard to watch but almost as hard to watch were the verbal and emotional rape sequences leading up to them.There were some vague "huh how did that happen' moments after the rapes that could have been explained better.  The revenge scenes were brutal - but fit the crimes. The movie definitely deserved its NR rating.  This is not one I would recommend anyone under the age of 18 seeing and a lot of adults won't want to see the violence either.  But I think it was well made for the type of movie it is.  Good actors, good camera work (too good sometimes).Edited June 6, 2011:I just watched the 1978 versionI Spit on Your Grave - Day of the Woman.  I was very impressed with it.  Both versions have their strengths.  The cinematography on the original was superb - clear, wonderful color, interesting perspectives.  There was no background musical score and I think that added a lot to the movie - you could hear every sound and the silences added to the drama.The 2011 version had much more of a psychological/emotional buildup to the rapes, which added to the scare factor.  And the revenge sequence in the newer movie was much more brutal.  Also, I thought the part of Matthew was much better played in the newer version, not such a caricature of a mentally troubled young man.In the 1978 version, there was more nudity - male and female; much more solely physical rape scenes - I can definitely understand the NR rating, ESPECIALLY for 1978. An extra on the DVD for this version is a discussion with the director, Meir Zarchi, which was enlightening.The stories aren't exactly alike but both are very good, for the genre they are. Both actresses playing Jennifer Hills - Camille Keaton (1978) and Sarah Butler (2010) did outstanding jobs.

reviewText: I must preface this by saying that before this movie's remake was released, I wasn't even aware that there was an original version.  Thus, I'm not going to arduously analyze which one is better, more shocking, influential, et cetera ad nauseam, but am going to treat this as the fantastically brutal film that it is in and of itself.Quite simply, I Spit on Your Grave is one of the best revenge shockers I've seen in quite some time.  Lead actress Sarah Butler is simply phenomenal in her role as the protagonist Jennifer Hills, a young writer who seeks solace in a remote cabin to seek inspiration for her creative writing.  Very early in, she is emotionally, physically, and finally sexually assaulted by a ragtag band of rednecks including a mentally challenged man (Chad Lindberg, perhaps the best performance aside from Butler's) and a local police officer.  Anyone lucky enough to not know the plot of the original classic will be wonderfully surprised, as Hills proceeds to hunt down, torture, and kill her perpetrators by the most hideous and imaginative of ways.Suffice it to say, even lovers of brutal horror and gore films will be challenged here.  The brilliant cinematography yields sickening special effects, and the bloody scenes will remain with you long after you sit down to watch.  The inevitable rape scene, though necessary to fuel the viewer's rage and hate at Hills' attackers, is difficult to sit through for numerous reasons, not the least of which is the deep vulnerability of Hills prior to that horrifying event.  If you can persist past that scene, however, you are in for a treat - not since the recent movie Taken have I been so fired up at the response of the film's victim to obstacles, and not since Hostel have I been so pleased by the results of the torture Hills inflicts on those which have inexplicably drawn her to unending rage and madness.All in all, this film is a delight, but for the most stalwart of fans:  disturbing, sickening, and redeeming, all in its own right.  I Spit on Your Grave indeed!

Tense music and doors banging in the wind suddenly along with a girl walking around barely clothed in the woods just seem to string the audience along until the rape scenes (that's right, more than one) finally take place. It's incredibly hard to watch and practically unbearable. Rape is really the furthest thing from entertaining, but that's probably the point with this kind of film. It gives the audience a chance to be in Jennifer's shoes. Not that they'd want to be. You're forced into knowing the hell she went through so that her revenge seems that much sweeter in the long run.Jennifer's revenge in the film on the men that did this to her is really the main reason to see this. The film is still far from charming, but the second half is captivating in a sick kind of way while revenge is where the film's creativity lies. Jennifer's use of fish hooks, a bear trap, duct tape, lye, hedge clippers, pliers, and a shotgun are all done in pretty unique ways. The horror fan in me that craves blood and gore was strangely satisfied seeing these men get what they deserved while the other side of me that is looking for another fun and entertaining trip to the movie theater was disgusted.There were a few concepts in the film that made me raise an eyebrow other than the obvious. Some of the things that came out of the mouths of this group of cliche rednecks were beyond asinine, but that was probably the point. The whole "pretty little showhorse" routine was just bizarre. After the first rape scene where the men make their exit and leave Jennifer alone, she wanders off into the woods with nothing on below the waist. Besides being in a drugged-like state and being in shock, it just seemed like one of those situations in a horror movie that ends with you yelling at the screen wondering why the character didn't do anything else instead. You also never really find out what happened to the sheriff's daughter. Why she wasn't involved in a larger capacity in that final trap is kind of mindboggling. I was expecting her to be in Matthew's place or at least be forced to watch the tape of what her dad had been busy doing out there on the job. Lastly, since when does a writer from the city know how to set up these traps? It's like Jennifer dated MacGyver or something. The same people who complained about Jason in the Friday the 13th remake are going to have a field day with this concept alone.I Spit on Your Grave is incredibly reminiscent of The Last House on the Left. It's an exploitation film that pushes the boundaries of what the audience can sit through without becoming completely nauseated and leaving altogether. It's not really something that can be watched for entertainment value or the best decision for a film to see on your first date. This film is not an easy watch and makes you feel surprisingly unclean after taking this horrendous journey. The only way I Spit on Your Grave can really be recommended is if you're wanting to test the waters to see how excessively sadistic and disturbing film's being released in theaters in the present day can really be.

Not only that, she brings a laptop hooked up to the internet with her in order to write this 'magnificently groundbreaking' manuscript to make Moby Dick read like a fishing story at the local creek and for some bizarre reason she can't finish it where she lives. Ever heard of a library? Are we really expected to believe that there is absolutely no way she could finish this book unless she travels all the way to this archaic cabin in the middle of nowhere? Even if the story is about a protaganist who is actually staying in a completely isolated cabin in the sticks, can't she just imagine it anyway? She lies about calling her boyfriend with her broken cellphone in order to hopefully scare off her attackers which is fine and stays consistent with our basic human reaction to a threat or perceived danger anyway. The problem is this is a lie in more ways than one because we know that she is single. No guy is going to wait around for weeks and weeks before he can see her again while she dedicates herself to her career.In the original it is much easier to believe Keaton's version on Hills is single because of the nerdy academic quality she brings to the character. reviewText: I watched this movie very reluctantly, as I usually do not like horror-remakes. The form has become incredibly trendy, and the remakes rarely hold a candle to the originals. However, I was pleasantly surprised by the remake of "I Spit On Your Grave".First of all, as the viewer, you need to know what you are getting into here when you are watching this film. If you aren't familiar with the original 1978 film, it was an absolutely brutal exploration of rape and revenge. The remake actually stays fairly close to the original, except the remake was filmed 32 years later, which means that the violence and the sexual assaults have been elevated to an absolutely extreme level. As far as I'm concerned, AWESOME! Yet, I know that lots of people are going to call this film "trash" or "porn" simply because it deals with the topic of brutal rape. There are plenty of ghastly and grisly images in modern horror films, yet everyone seems to think that rape is absolutely the most offensive and the worst violence you can commit to film. To me, it's not much different from the type of violence you would find in films like "Saw" (series), "Hostel" (series), "Martyrs", "Frontier(s)" "Inside" or "The Human Centipede". But, I know some people just can't handle something about rape scenes. If you are one of these people, you need to search elsewhere for entertainment. Even though the sexual assault scenes really don't take up that much screen time, they are pretty degrading and nasty (nothing like you'd see in "Irreversible", but this film's sexual assaults can keep up with about any other rape you've ever seen on film). DO YOU THINK I'M SICK YET?? Hahaha, ok, maybe you have a point. However, I'm not especially thrilled watching rape scenes in horror. To me, it's not very creative, although it has an incredible power to shock people. Yet, I was actually way more uncomfortable watching the rest of the violence in the film. I'm trying not to write any spoilers, but let's just say there are some "traps" that the "Saw" franchise would be jealous of. Absolutely vicious. This was the most satisfying element of the film for me. If you like your horror tough and brutal, you very well may like this film.You must remember a few other things going into this film. This is not the kind of film that's going to get critical praise. The plot is virtually non-existent. Or at least, it's very, very simple. I didn't find this to be a huge problem, because the sequence of events in the film form the story. The dialogue is INCREDIBLY cheesy, to the point of making your skin crawl as much as the violence in the film. Also, the acting is somewhat sub-par (with the exception of Sarah Butler's performance in the lead role). It's the only element of the film that doesn't seem real, which I think detracts from the overall value of a serious horror film. There's also a loose end that isn't tied up at the end of the film, which left me scratching my head wondering why they didn't address what happened to this particular character. These problems are very common in horror films (as most people know), so if you know what you're about to watch and you allow yourself to be entertained, these little problems don't seriously detract from the overall experience of the film. These few negative elements led me to give this film 3.5 stars instead of 4.5, which it would have earned simply for the level of violence and intensity. Overall, as far as horror-remakes go, this one is one the better ones, IMO. I probably still like the original better, due to the novelty of 70's horror films, but I'd actually say it's a fairly close race, and I never say that about these remakes. If you are a fan of this type of cinema, I'd say it's definitely worth a view. 3.5 stars.

Then the second half the hillbillies realize she's still alive and enacting revenge on them, and it completely follows them around for the last half of the movie.My problem with this is if you're going to show a character go through a long and torturous hell, you better develop the character, otherwise we might as well be watching a high quality snuff film. The woman after her horrific ordeal is never on camera again unless she's torturing someone, *snore*. After she fell into the river I would've been much MUCH more interested in seeing her frantically escape her captors, collect herself again, and then exact revenge. If you take time to develop the character, her motives, and illustrate her mentality more the revenge part has more of an impact than. If you just jump to the violence, skipping all character development than all the meaning is lost, and that's exactly what the director did with this film, he chose the easy way.So instead of the film showing us character development it pads itself out with useless scenes such as the hillbillies arguing and complaining. We don't need to see the hillbillies that much, we know they're bad, we can assume they're probably pissed off they lost the girl, and we know the girl is going to get her revenge just by looking at the cover. The director either A) doesn't know how to film a scene WITHOUT someone getting horribly mutilated/tortured and B) assumes the audience is so rabid with bloodlust that we don't want to have our time wasted by anything else. I'm going to guess the answer is (A) though because even if this was just a splatter flick we still get some boring filler scenes.So finally we get to the part we've been waiting for, the girl's revenge, and I do admit the death scene with the crows was creative and gruesome, but otherwise it's like some cheap SAW knock-off that involves penises and anuses more, basically if you haven't gotten the idea this film's purpose is to be disgusting as possible. One by one the characters are taken captive through the power of plot convienence. This would've been another instance where the narritive should've focused on the girl hunting down her targets, plotting her next move and giving the audience an insight into her character's intellect more, instead we get scenes where the main hillbilly shouts on his front lawn "I KNOW YOU'RE OUT THERE". Eventually she takes them all out then sits outside and stares at the camera. The End!So after sitting through a 40 minute rape and watching graphic violence, I wondered why the hell I just sat through I Spit on your Grave. Gore and shock can be great additions to give a movie more of a bite, just look at Robocop; but in this movie the centerpiece IS gore and violence. I Spit on your Grave is boring when people aren't getting tortured and unnecessarily repulsive when they are. If you want yet another Craven remake the Hills Have Eyes and Last House on the Left have much more fleshed out and interesting characters that the audience can grow to care for. If you just want to see how disgusting a movie can get there are countless better ones that spare the boring details such as August Underground Mordum, the Guniea Pig series, or even the recent Human Centipede 2. This movie is like some bastard child between these cult gore-fests and a profitable/appealing hollywood remake, and the whole outcome is just a boring and repulsive mess. I wouldn't recommend this movie to my worst enemy.

reviewText: It's easy to review this movie, especially after seeing the highly controversial original from Meir Zarchi. Why? Because it's just a version for a large audience, as predictable as possible, when the original was only for adults! See this: Camille Keaton (grand-niece of Buster Keaton) was 31 when she starred in Zarchi's 1978 almost no-budget original, which came out when rape and revenge storytelling was anything but fashioned. Sarah Butler was 24 when she starred in the remake. So? The mature, aristocratic female in the original has been replaced with a little tease, escaped from the worst TV series and who moves and speaks and dresses up like any common student. She's silly enough to get lost when she has a map (and works for a magazine lol) so she has to ask around for her way. Bad luck, the guy who gives her the info is the same one who'll fall down on her later, with his mates. Predictable? You got it! In the original, Jennifer doesn't ask for her way to the cabin so we never know who will fall down on her and how - we call this suspense. When it happens, it's surprising because it's in daytime, on a river. Totally unexpected. In the remake, it's different (at night, inside her cabin!) but we can see everything coming right away, very quickly, especially after the camcorder precision. No suspense!The rape scenes (two in a row, instead of three in the original) are shocking but they totally lack the cold realism of the original, thanks to - or because of? - Jennifer who keeps weeping like a baby, and the shaking camera. The filmmakers (like most horror directors today) say goodbye to style and cold realism, they do nothing else but shoot from one angle to another and use frantic editing that makes everything, even the simulated sexual moves, look desperately flat. So flat that the film can be followed with the sound off. The movie tries to surprise without managing to do it - it's not the goal after all -, especially with that sherif who passes for honest but happens to be as degenerate as the others, even more since he has a family. The film starts to be interesting only after Jennifer jumps in the river and mysteriously disappears, in front of the thugs (how could she stay totally out of sight for so long?) but Monroe, the director, wastes everything with plans taken from "Ring" as she brutally re-appears in a ghost-like way, with her long black hair partly hiding her face, then from the "Saw" series as she takes on the thugs one after another. She always does the same thing, taking them by surprise and knocking them down, preferably from behind, so they wake up in the most uncomfortable positions ever. It's such a piece of cake for her that the movie loses all of its interest - it didn't have much so far - from the moment we catch her revenge method. She looks to much like Shawnee 'Amanda' Smith in the "Saw" series to be totally convincing. Thing is, unlike Amanda in "Saw", Jennifer hasn't been showed and taught anything about torture 'art', so what the film shows can be described as impossible.Many people say that the revenge scenes in Zarchi's original are poorly executed, maybe because they didn't satisfy their needs and thirst for 'voyeurism' at a time when image and real TV shows have invaded everything. I personally found them shocking - especially the scene in the bathtub, which has been removed for the remake and replaced with very common, predictable torture stuff. The thug is chained to the ceiling when Jennifer cuts his thing off (too easy!), when he's not in the original - she sexually manipulates him. Apparently the lesson hasn't been taken. And where do all those ropes and chains and perfectly cut pieces of wood come from anyway? Why does she need to use all this crap? How can she show so much ingenuity and cleverness during her revenge when she looks so traumatized? On the whole this movie is violent of course but that's all, it's shocking but grotesque at the same time, the revenge scenes are repetitive and go uselessly way too far. I saw it just after the original so it never surprised me when the original did.If you want to be surprised, there are way better films around - notably some from the 70's-80's-90's. Today the fashion is to remakes with no intention to surprise anybody, just to allow us to see as many things as possible without thinking too much. The 'I Spit On Your Grave' original was cold, decent and new for its time, this remake is just exploitation of violence for the masses. Not to be recommended.

reviewText: The 2010 remake of I Spit on Your Grave, is a better made, better acted movie than the original. Wheither or not the film as a whole is better than the original is up for debate, and I guess would depend upon your tastes.The remake is still a film you will find difficult to watch with other people, as the rape scene is just as brutal as in the original, albeit, thankfully, a bit shorter. It brutally gets the point across but does not over utilize the gratuitous nudity of the original film. The scene does what it is designed to do, to make you hate the five men enough that you want to see them dead.The story is pretty much the same, but the acting is much better than in the original, and the characters are much more believable and more developed, so to speak. There is however, the cliche of the rednecks in the woods terrorising the city girl, that is overused in horror movies.Sarah Butler plays her role as the victim very well, and when it comes to the revenge scenes, you are really wanting to see the antagonists get what they have coming. I liked the fact that she didn't have to take her clothes off in order to exact revenge, which is something that just never made sense to me in the original. I did think though, that the revenge scenes were rather unrealistic with the use of complicated traps, which makes you wonder what Jennifer's relationship is to MacGyver or Jigsaw from the Saw films. But I found myself happy with the outcome anyway, despite it being over-the-top.I would say if you are a fan of the original, or are a fan of revenge flicks in general, you'll appreciate this film. If you are not a fan of this type of film, just stay away. I never have understood those people that understand full-well what they are getting into going in, but go and watch anyway just so they can turn around and write a scathing review about the content. It goes without saying that this film is not for everyone.This Blu-Ray had excellent picture and sound, but I felt was lacking in the special features department. The feature commentary I found to be rather boring and uninformative. There is a generic "making of" featurette, a couple deleted scenes and some trailers. I would have liked to hear from the filmmakers about why they wanted to remake the 1978 original, what they thought of it, what they were trying to improve upon, etc. But, then again, I'm a big special features kind of guy. If they are no big deal to you and you are just looking to enjoy the movie, I think you'll be satisfied with this.

reviewText: I Spit on Your Grave, originally titled Day of the Woman, was a 1978 film that was notoriously vile garbage somewhat noteworthy for being dissected brutally by Roger Ebert in his scathing synchronal zero star review.  But still, it was notoriously vile garbage before anything else quite like it was ever made, and believe it or not in some circles that counts for something, if only for being the first of its kind.  Additionally, the original film may have been meant as a pro-feminist reaction to violence against women created by an idiot who doesn't know how to make movies, but obviously its a stretch to find any artistic merit at all.  So now, some 32 years later we get a remake that we can assume not only contains even more diluted messages for its defenders but also even more ammunition for its detractors, especially given the feminist movement in the United States has really been inactive for pretty much the same three decades since the release of the original film.  It doesn't matter though because some horror films today believe they are beyond having artistic value and somehow immune toward scrutiny of their motives.  The I Spit On Your Grave remake is not quite as shocking and disgusting as the original considering the time period, but it is even more shameful for being long, stupid, gratuitous torture porn that contains some horrifically bad acting and writing.  It is truly one of the most disdainful pieces of filth I've had the displeasure of enduring in quite some time.  It is crucial to note that my distaste for this movie is less so for its unsettling content than for how the actors are mismanaged and likely untalented anyway, and because they are reciting foolish dialogue.In case you didn't know already I Spit On Your Grave is a movie about a girl named Jenny (Sarah Butler) who retreats to a cabin in the middle of nowhere to write.  She is haunted by the ultimate redneck stereotypes who eventually rape her.  The second half of the film covers her violent revenge, which contains some insanely implausible and unfortunately nowadays all-too-typical over the top horror-film violence.  Both the rape scene and the revenge scenes are what makes this movie appealing to someone out there.  The sexual violence in this movie is the solitary reason for its existence and no one sensible person can dispute otherwise.  Obviously I have an issue with that and if you don't, well, enjoy your movie.I cringe giving this movie any credit whatsoever, but its star Sarah Butler can be partially exonerated.  She is perhaps a bit too pretty for this kind of movie and actually seems to have found some inspiration to act here in flashes.  She might even have talent.  I don't know why that happened but I sort of feel sorry for her.  It's actually a brave role and maybe she intended to show someone out there what she is willing to sacrifice.  Its other young actors are simply not good enough to defend but I don't want to blame them too much either.  In fact, the blame lies almost exclusively with the very idea that this kind of film can and probably will make money.  The irresponsible interaction between huckster and suckered patron is the real story here.  Please don't pay a dime to see this movie.

reviewText: With the resurgence of exploitation films, we've really brought some unpleasantly vicious movies into the mainstream. Some are good, some are not--just like any genre--but what is fascinating to me is how commonplace they now seem. When I was growing up, pictures like the original "I Spit On Your Grave," "Faces of Death" and "Last House on the Left" were considered vile films and they had to be discovered. A largely underground, low budget, and independent film community had to support these controversial, malicious films. In many ways, they represented a rebellion against conventional entertainment.  However, by today's standards these films, while certainly grim, are relatively subdued compared to the graphic torture, violence and gore that delight audiences at the local mall.Designed to provoke audiences, one thing is certain--few people will be ambivalent about the new incarnation of "I Spit On Your Grave."  I know people who think it's terrific AND I know people who think that it is repellant.  Just the latest example of the growing market I like to refer to as "torture cinema," ISOYG will have very few viewers straddling the middle ground.  While the original film played to the time it was released--there was almost a female empowerment message in the retribution scenario--this new version eschews a specific societal context.  Much more gore oriented than its predecessor, it feels distinctly less real.  That is either good or bad depending on your vantage point. The amateurish quality of the original lends it a gritty realism that actually works in the film's favor.  Combined with Camille Keaton's surprisingly effective performance, the film had the flavor of something that could actually happen.  The new version is decidedly more elaborate and the revenge conceptions are more over-the-top.  The enjoyment value, thus, is determined by whether graphic brutality qualifies as entertainment for you.I haven't said much about the film's plot.  I think most people know what happens.  A young woman is sexually assaulted by a group of men, brutalized, and left for dead.  She reemerges with vengeance on her mind--and the men will rue the day they met her.  Sarah Butler as the victim in question has some nice moments, but exists largely to service the plot.  For me, she lacked the genuineness of Keaton.  The men are slightly more developed in this new vision.  While barely more than caricatures in either film, they have more shading here--and the mentally challenged character is conceptualized more fully in this edition.  The film remains unrepentantly bleak and disturbing and pushes buttons for the sake of pushing buttons.  There is no grand meaning to be had--but, quite frankly, I don't think that's why anyone would be watching in the first place.Mind you, I'm not claiming either version of "I Spit On Your Grave" is a great movie.  I do, however, believe that the original was more relevant in relationship to its time period.  But this new film is made with technical prowess and visual flair (however unpleasant).  Some may claim these films as a feminist treatise, and some as vile female degradation. In truth, they are actually a bit of both--but I don't think that they necessarily merit a serious philosophical discussion. Either way, this film was meant to assault your senses--and that it does!  On it's own merits, it succeeds at what it set out to do.  If you like gore, you may well like this.  If you don't, by all means, stay far far away!  KGHarris, 2/11.
summary: Don't Let The Charming Title Fool You!  Love it Or Loathe It, This Assault On The Senses Will Elicit Strong Emotions

reviewText: Okay so the truth is there is no spitting nor are there any graves in either the original or remade version of I SPIT ON YOUR GRAVE. The title was made by producer Jerry Gross for the original film in order to get film bookers in the south to book the film again, which had already failed in cut form under the title DAY OF THE WOMAN. With the additional removed sequences back in place, a take that MPAA attitude, a sensational and unforgettable ad campaign and tons of free publicity when Ebert & Siskel slammed the film (hard to believe Ebert could do so after watching his BEYOND THE VALLEY OF THE DOLLS which he scripted), the film went on to make history.And now Hollywood, in its never ending search for something new...okay no not new...in their attempt to remake every movie ever made, we get this latest version of the film. It follows the same basic story. Jennifer Hill (this time played by Sarah Butler) comes to a country retreat for a month only to be sought out by gas station attendant Johnny (Jeff Branson) and his pals.This time around the gang seems more backwater good ole boys than even the original displayed. Is it any wonder country folk have no use for big city folk when they are constantly portrayed this way? Anyway, the group attacks and rapes Jennifer more than once and in more than one location. ***SPOILER ALERT*** When she contacts the local sheriff to come to her cabin in the woods for help she learns too late that he's part of this group as well. Having been raped and sodomized by this group, Jennifer crawls home and plots her revenge.The same plotline passes here as she takes her time trapping each one and taking out her vengeance in the most brutal ways possible. While the rape sequences of Jennifer are as disturbing as they were in the original, the revenge sequences here take up more time than they did in 1978. Not only that but her methods fall more in line with today's images of torture than those in the original. The original was more about her just exacting her revenge with only one taking any amount of time. Here, she slowly does unmentionable deeds to each of her protagonists, with something especially disgusting in store for the sheriff.With more money to spend this version of the film has a much crisper look to it. The photography is well done, the acting intense and believable and the story continues to promote the genre of film known as revenge movies. Does it leave you with a bad taste in your mouth like the first one did? Yes, it does.Its one thing to make an original film and not know what the audience will think of it. Its quite another to take a disturbing film and make it over again, adding little more than well done gore and more over the top kill scenes. When released the film didn't do much at the box office. Perhaps that means that the audience for what is known as torture porn films is dwindling. We can only hope.Does the film offer anything new? Not that I could see. Yes, the performances were well done, yes it had a polished look to it. But is it a movie that you'll want to stick on the shelf next to BAMBI and MARY POPPINS? Not likely.

reviewText: In I SPIT ON YOUR GRAVE (1978), aspiring novelist Camille Keaton rents a house in the country one summer and is soon raped, beaten and left for dead by four local thugs.  She recovers but, instead of going to the law, decides to get her own just, ghastly revenge on the quartet.The movie contained a considerable amount of graphic nudity, and both the rape and revenge sequences were quite brutal and realistic.  Of course, during the revenge sequences, one felt like cheering every time Ms. Keaton dispatched one of her attackers.Steven R. Monroe directed the 2010 remake of I SPIT ON YOUR GRAVE, which stars Sarah Butler, who does quite well in the Keaton role.Though the heroine's methods of revenge in this version are much more brutal, the screenplay follows the general plot of the 1978 picture.  It does add one key character, who I won't talk about lest I be a Spoiler, but the addition of this character certainly makes the story more intriguing.There is still some graphic nudity in 2010 version, but not as much as there was in 1978.Extras on this DVD include director and producer (Lisa Hansen) commentary and a "Making of" featurette.There are a many extremely dark and disturbing scenes in this version, which some people will not be able to watch.  Still, if you could sit through the SAW movies, I guess that I SPIT ON YOUR GRAVE will not be too much of a problem. Michael B. Druxman

reviewText: I'll start off by saying I never saw the original. I've heard how it's a grindhouse/cult classic, but I never had a chance to see it so I went into I Spit on your Grave (2010) without any background to compare it to. I'd imagine die-hard fans of the original might be disappointed in the same way remakes of almost ANY Movie would be disappointed (regardless of how good it was). Throw in the fact it's basically a Starz Direct-to-Video movie (VERY short run on no more than a dozen theaters) with a 1.5Mil budget, making very little of that back.I was expecting to be disappointed, but hoping for the best.I must say, the movie was disturbing at times, it was disgusting at times, but I loved it! I think many will find issue with what goes on in the movie, and I completely see why, but you have to remember it's a movie. I'm very against all of that, but in the same way I can watch JAWS explode, zombies attack people or people deal with Jigsaw's deadly traps in other movies, you just have to remember it's a movie. With the themes being more "real" in this one, it's not for everyone (and if that doesn't get you, the violence will!)For horror lovers, this is a very good movie. It's not watered down to be a PG-13 movie, it's a hard "R" at least. Despite the themes (trying to avoid any spoilers here, for those who don't know the story), it's not a depressing movie. It's a good revenge-movie in the style of Kill Bill, and some of the payback will have you disgusted while cheering the main character on. To some, that may sound like the worst movie ever, and for those I recommend against it. For everyone else, check it out.It's high on (graphic) violence and nudity, so it's definitely one for adults only.For the Blu-Ray itself, video is VERY nice (I believe it was filmed with the RED camera), same for audio. It's not a direct-to-video 'junk' release, they actually put some time and effort into making it look and sound good.The extras are a commentary and about 30 minutes of cast/crew interviews. I'll admit I skipped over most of these as a lot of the cast seemed completely clueless about what they were making ("I told my sister about the script and she said thats a remake of "I spit on your grave!" - I never saw the movie, but I knew I had to do it then!")

reviewText: First of all, let me warn you that this is no ordinary "thriller" or "suspense." Steven R. Monroe' remake of the1978 cult revenge film is very violent with a lengthy rape scene that goes on and on. "I Spit on Your Grave" is not "Kill Bill" where over-the-top violence is counterbalanced by dark humor and actions, and it doesn't want to be. Here the violence is raw and shocking, and it is meant that way.The story itself is very simple. A writer from a city Jennifer Hills (Sarah Butler) rents a cabin in the woods to write a new book. She is attacked and raped by the local men. A month later she returns to them for ultimate revenge.The film takes an extremely long time to show what happens to Jennifer, and like in a controversial French film "Irréversible," the graphic violence is something that makes you feel very uncomfortable. Also, don't expect some social messages in the grindhouse-type film. Again, whatever the film is, it is not "The Accused" or "The Brave One," but I think you already know that.What disappointed me is the way the vengeful heroine distributes her own brand of justice. They are cruel - which is fine with me - and too elaborate, as if copying the tortures in the "Saw" franchise. Jennifer's transformation from a writer from a city into a killer who can create Jigsaw-like torture methods is not very convincing, especially after seeing the heroine's realistic rape and humiliation scenes. And ... how did she survive in the woods (without being seen) for such a long time?"I Spit on Your Grave" is a repulsive film. It is brutal and disturbing, but the real problem is that I cannot see the point of it at all.

reviewText: Director Meir Zarchi's 'DAY OF THE WOMAN' gets a modern retro upgrade in Director Steven R. Monroe's harrowing remake of 'I SPIT ON YOUR GRAVE'.  Since the original was made during the upheaval of the seventies with the Vietnam war and the cinemas changing persona, the grit and grain upgraded Zarchi's low budget entry into cult classic status.  Now in the modern age of the 'SAW' and 'HOSTEL' franchises not to mention the remake of 'LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT', his vision was ripe for a definitive version.  All the harrowing traumas of the original are given detail that could never have been dreamed of in the seventies.  Now we have cam-corders filming Jennifer Hill's rape and also her filming one of her episodes of revenge.  Computers and cellphones are also in the picture but the real improvement is the background development of each of the protaganists making Jennifer's retaliation all the more deserved.  Sarah Butler as Jennifer is not as gritty as Camille Keaton's original performance but it definitely gets the job done.  Warning, to viewers who have not seen the original, this is pretty strong stuff including the violation of Jennifer's character so be warned.  As far as remakes go, this is one of the best and since Meir Zarchi also has an executive producers credit, he should be comfortable in knowing that his vision has finally been fulfilled in all of its blood soaked glory.  Viva La Feminine!!!!
